section.title: Personalization
section.para: It is recommended that you specify a dedicated directory for your personalized settings in Oracle JDeveloper 12c. Especially on a Windows Operating System this helps to keep the huge amount of data JDeveloper creates during usage out of the User Profile this Operating System manage for you.
section.important: On a Windows Operating System the User Profile may be synchronized to a network device if you shut down the computer you are logged on. If the User Profile exceeds the limits configured by the Domain Administrator the changes you did at all will not be synchronized anymore.
section.note: If you are working on different PCâ€™s over the time this directory should be a share on a network device where you have access to all the time.
section.para: Two options exsists to configure such a directory. Either you use a command line switch to start Oracle JDeveloper 12c or you configuring in the property file <ORACLE_HOME>/jdeveloper/ide/bin/ide.conf
section.note: If you share the workstation with other developers the command line switch is the recommended option to configure such a directory.

section.title: Memory Settings
section.para: Open in a text editor the file <ORACLE_HOME>/jdeveloper/ide/bin/ide.conf.

note.para: If you share the workstation with other developers you should make this changes in your personalized product configuration.
The location of user/product files are often configured during installation, but may be found in:
In particular, the directives to set the initial and maximum Java memory and the SetJavaHome directive to specify the JDK location can be overridden in that file instead of modifying the global file.

section.para: The format of this file is Directive Value with one or more spaces between the directive and the value. E.g AddVMOption -Xms2048M.

row.entry: Specify the initial size, in bytes, of the memory allocation pool. This value must be a multiple of 1024 greater than 1MB. Append the letter k or K to indicate kilobytes, or m or M to indicate megabytes, or g or G to indicate gigabytes.

Specify the maximum size, in bytes, of the memory allocation pool. This value must be a multiple of 1024 greater than 2MB. Append the letter k or K to indicate kilobytes, or m or M to indicate megabytes, or g or G to indicate gigabytes.

section.title: Garbage Collector Settings
section.para: Open in a text editor the file <ORACLE_HOME>/jdeveloper/ide/bin/jdev.conf.

note.para: If you share the workstation with other developers you should make this changes in your personalized product configuration.
The location of user/product files are often configured during installation, but may be found in:

section.para: The format of this file is Directive Value with one or more spaces between the directive and the value. E.g ddVMOption -XX:+UseStringCache.

row.entry: If on a 64-bit system, but using less than 32 GB RAM, this reduces object pointer memory size.
Use an aggressive garbage collector (constant small collections).

section.warning: We would caution you on enabling -XX:+AggressiveOpts breaks offline database support in JDeveloper so that one will have to be avoided in some cases.

section.title: Extension Settings
section.para: It is recommended to load the core extension at startup of the IDE.
This option configures the set of features that will be loaded on startup (the ide-core feature is always loaded on startup, but you can specify a comma-delimited list of additional feature ids)
